sense.name: fix or match to a certain rate or level
sense.commentary: NOTE: Usually in a financial frame; progress or evolution of NP1 is tied to NP2. Most financial examples will be this sense.
sense.examples: The Hong Kong currency is pegged to the U.S. dollar. The minimum wage has traditionally been pegged at half the average U.S. manufacturing wage.

sense.name: identify (as being in a particular category); attribute to a cause.
sense.examples: He pegged speech recognition and wireless networking as two technologies that will have a big impact in the future. He says Aidan is a lot smarter than he pegged him for. Wow guys he pegged it. We need to sign famous people. McNeill said he's pegged Cory Fowler to handle onside kickoffs. I can't seem to peg down the rules of this game. Right now the future is too hard to peg down.

sense.name: attach or fix with pegs
sense.examples: Have you pegged down the tent yet? He pegged shoes for 10 dollars a month for 8 years. Then he worked in a cotton mill for 33 cents a day.

sense.name: hit accurately
sense.examples: He's pegged a few birds already out by the neighborhood pond. He pegged out all three balls.

sense.name: work steadily
sense.examples: For a time the young composer dutifully pegged away at the University of Helsingfors.
